sen.j: 筋（すじ）とは、江戸時代に地勢によって区分された行政区画をいう。
sen.e: Suji is an administrative district that were created in the Edo Period, according to geographical conditions.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の勘定所では、天領を関東筋・東海道筋・北国筋・畿内筋・中国筋・西国筋と区分した。
sen.e: The kanjosho of the Edo shogunate divided the country into Kanto-suji, Tokaido-suji, Hokkoku-suji, Kinai-suji, Chugoku-suji and Saikoku-suji.

sen.j: 美濃国には各郡に筋名が見られ、近江の彦根藩では南・中・北の3筋があり、各筋ごとに筋奉行が交通・駅伝・衣食住・年貢収納などを管轄し、その下で代官が分担執務した。
sen.e: Suji-related names are seen very often in the provinces of Mino, with three suji--Minami, Naka and Kita--in Omi's Hikone domain. Each suji was administered by its own suji-bugyo (magistrate) controlling transportation, ekiden stations for messengers, everyday needs in food and supplies, and collection of taxies in kind, with daikan (local governors) working under the bugyo.

In Mino province, Suji-related names were seen in each district, Hikone domain of Omi had three Sujis consisting of Minami, Naka and Kita per which each Suji-bugyo (shogunate administrator) administered traffic, Ekiden (transportation system), supplies for living and collection of tax, with daikan (local governors) who was subordinated to bugyo to share works.
